reviewText: Junk food addicted Lemur under heavy fire"You are a lemur
date: you know that thing from Madagascar. Your goal is to collect a certain number of junk food items til the end of each level. Basically Lemurzin is just a simple sidescroller with unique and cute graphics. So far so good.  But the game mechanics are horrible and partly quite unfair and gamebreaking. You will be chased in 20 levels by a shooting turtle cop. Unfortunately you can just dodge up and down
hoursPlayed: and don't shoot back at all. That must be only deadly. For example when there are obstacles like bombs in front of you and the turtle throwing 3 bullets in the same lane. Or caves drop stalagtites hitting you every damn time (that's where I'm stuck atm). Sloppy hitboxes and clunky controls as hell. Sometimes it seems you can just go up
voteText: middle or down but nothing in between. What a pity. If there weren't those issues it could be a nice little fun game with some easy achievements."

voteText: trading cards and achievements can justify anything
helpfulPercent: but not in this case. Overall feeling - "Let's port it quickly and make some cash
votesHelpful: doesn't matter how much because it's still better than nothing".\n\nP.S. Be careful about positive reviews - most of them were made by users who either spent in game hardly 10 minutes or have about 10 games on their accounts without any other reviews besides one for this particular "game". At least one of them was written by the developer himself - but even developer didn't play it's own game: playtime is about 3 hours and no achievements unlocked. That's nonsense because in 30 minutes it's easy to unlock 9 of 15 achievements."

reviewText:
Holy crap, is this game bad.  It's a horrible port of a horrible mobile game, and I use the word 'port' very, very loosely.  If you really want to subject yourself to this disaster, grab the free mobile version:

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.kitstupid.lemurzin&hl=en

and then smack yourself with your phone for doing so.

Pros:  There are trading cards...?
Cons:  Selling the trading cards will give money to the 'developers' of this pile of steaming garbage.
Other Cons:  Everything else.

reviewText:
Lemurzin is a middling game, neither particularly good nor particularly bad, just meh.
However, it does have some problems.

The game is a 2D collecting and dodging game.
You play the part of a lemur (an animal which looks like a cross between a monley and a possum), who is being chased and shot at by a turtle cop.
The lemur has to avoid the shotgun blasts, as well as various floating bombs and other explosives, while at the same time collecting various foodstuffs floating in the air.

Unfortunately, the play-interactive edges of the lemur and the bombs are not well-defined, so you may think you have avoided a bomb, but you blow up instead. I tried to play the game by estimating the invisible edges of the game items, which seemed to work relatively well, but should not have to be how the game is played.

It appears that Lemurzin has been brought over to PCs from a mobile phone platform, without being fully adapted.
Hence, at the beginning, it tells you to tap screen to start".
The exit button won't let you exit the game
date: which possibly comes from the same issue.\n\nI found the game more annoying than fun; however- if I am in the mood for it and have nothing better to do - I may return to it to finish off the achievements. But
hoursPlayed: I might not.\n\nThere are far better games out there than Lemurzin. I would recommend that people give this one a miss."

reviewText: This would make for a decent mobile game if it had more to it and everything wasn't so random. I constantly find myself stuck mid-world 2 because the turtle keeps shooting so sporadically every single run that it's almost pure luck to accomplish and you get trapped and die. Also, this game is too simple for a $3 game (even though I bought it for $0.67).

reviewText: Lemurzin offers some astute, much-needed commentary on the state of criminal justice systems in many contemporary developing countries.\n\nA word of warning though - this game is harder than the trailer would suggest, and one or two achievements are even harder still. Combined with the very low quality of the game engine (collision detection, movement etc.) it creates a frustrating experience. If you're looking for something to 100% without any effort you might be in the wrong place.
